content: How can I help you today?

I've been having a really hard time sleeping lately. My mind won’t stop racing at night, and I just can’t seem to shut it off no matter what I try. It’s gotten to the point where I feel drained all the time, but I don’t know how to fix it.

That sounds really exhausting and frustrating, trying to rest while your mind feels like it’s racing nonstop. It makes sense that feeling so drained is taking a toll on you. What’s been keeping your mind so busy lately?

Work has been really stressful lately. I’m worried about losing my job because if that happens, I don’t know how I’d take care of my family. It’s like those thoughts just spiral out of control every night, and I can’t seem to escape them.

Worrying about your job and your family’s well-being sounds overwhelming, especially when those thoughts start spiraling and feel nonstop at night. It sounds like you care deeply about providing for your family, and that’s a lot of pressure to carry. How are you handling this stress during your days?

Honestly, during the day, I just try to push through and focus on work, but it’s like the stress builds up and comes crashing down at night. I’ll scroll on my phone to distract myself, but it usually just makes things worse. It feels like I’m stuck in this cycle, and I don’t really know how to break out of it.

It sounds like you've been doing your best to cope, even when it feels like the stress keeps building up. Scrolling on your phone might feel like an escape for a moment, but it seems like it hasn’t helped ease the bigger worries that are weighing you down. What do you think makes it so difficult to step out of this cycle at night?

I guess it’s because when I’m lying there in the quiet, all my worries get louder. Using my phone feels like a way to avoid those thoughts, but it ends up giving me more to think about, and then I’m just stuck again. It’s hard to know what else to do when I feel so restless.

It sounds like those quiet moments can make your worries feel even more intense, and using your phone feels like a quick distraction but doesn’t bring the relief you’re looking for. Feeling restless like that can make it hard to figure out how to shift things. What do you think might help bring a little calm or give your mind some space, even briefly?

Honestly, I don’t even know what would help anymore. I’ve thought about trying something like relaxing before bed or maybe not using my phone, but the moment I lie down, my brain just goes into overdrive again. It’s hard to even think of what would really work right now.

It sounds like you’ve already considered ways to calm down before bed, but it’s tough when your mind feels like it’s working against you the moment you lie down. That sounds frustrating and discouraging, especially when you’re doing your best to think of solutions. What has helped you feel even a little calmer during stressful times in the past?

It’s hard to say, but sometimes just talking to my partner or distracting myself with something small, like music or a movie, has helped a little. But when it comes to bedtime, nothing really sticks. It’s almost like no matter what I do, my thoughts just push their way in.

Talking to your partner and turning to music or movies seem like helpful ways to ease stress, even if it hasn’t carried over to bedtime. It sounds tough when those thoughts feel so overpowering, like they refuse to give you a break. What do you think makes talking to your partner or those distractions feel calming at times?

I think it’s because when I’m talking to my partner, I don’t feel so alone with all these thoughts. And with music or a movie, it’s like my mind has something else to focus on for a little while. But when I’m in bed, it’s just me and my racing brain, and it’s hard to shake that feeling.

It makes sense that talking to your partner helps you feel less alone and supported, while music or a movie gives your mind something to latch onto, even temporarily. But in bed, when it’s just you and your thoughts, it feels isolating and nonstop. Would you like to explore more ideas together to reduce that racing feeling at bedtime, or is there something else you’d like to share?
I think I would like to explore some ideas—I’m not sure what will help, but I’m open to hearing suggestions. It has to be something manageable though, because I already feel so tired and overwhelmed.

Thanks for sharing that you’re open to exploring ideas—being open when you’re already feeling tired and overwhelmed takes courage. Before we dive in, it might help to recap what we’ve talked about so far: you’ve been having trouble sleeping due to racing thoughts, mostly about work stress and family concerns. Distractions like talking to your partner or listening to music have helped some during the day, but nights feel harder as your worries grow louder in the quiet. Does that capture things so far? And is there anything else you’d like to add before we continue?
Yes, that pretty much sums it up. There’s nothing else I can think of to add right now, but I’m interested in hearing ways to help quiet my mind at night.

Thank you for confirming and for being open to exploring this together. Since it sounds like calming your mind at night feels like the biggest challenge, here’s a thought: Would you be interested in trying small steps to relax your body or gently redirect your focus before bed, like breathing exercises or something soothing like journaling to get thoughts out? These could be simple and manageable, but only if they feel like a good fit to you. What are your thoughts?
I’m okay to end the conversation here. Thank you for talking about all of this with me—I really appreciate it.
